question_details.query: In logged forests, is it better to retain riparian buffers or retain forested corridors to support bat populations?
What is the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, there are no studies that have directly evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome. The systematic searches have not found any studies assessing the success rate of such reintroductions. While there is evidence about breeding bats in captivity showing that reproductive success varies (6-100% of female bats successfully conceive and give birth in captivity), and survival rates of captive-born pups range from 20-100%, these studies do not address the specific challenge of reintroducing them into white-nose syndrome affected areas. The rehabilitation studies show that hand-reared orphaned bats have survival rates of 70-90% for at least 4-14 days after release into the wild, with some evidence of longer-term survival (up to nearly four years), but this is for rehabilitated bats rather than captive-bred individuals.
summary_statements: There are no studies that have directly evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.
Systematic searches have not found any studies assessing the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome.
Evidence on breeding bats in captivity shows that reproductive success varies, with 6-100% of female bats successfully conceiving and giving birth.
The survival rates of captive-born bat pups range from 20-100%.
Studies on the reproductive success and survival rates of captive-bred bats do not address the specific challenge of reintroducing the bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome.
Rehabilitation studies show that hand-reared orphaned bats have survival rates of 70-90% for at least 4-14 days after release into the wild.
There is some evidence of longer-term survival for hand-reared orphaned bats, with some surviving up to nearly four years.
The survival data from rehabilitation studies is for rehabilitated bats, not for captive-bred individuals.

question_details.query: Will training arborists to identify potential bat roosts (Action 1981) be more effective than protecting known roost trees during forest operations (Action 1982)?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Both Action 1981 (training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts) and Action 1982 (protecting roost trees during forest operations) have no available evidence regarding their effectiveness. According to the action documents, no studies have been found that evaluated the effects of either action on bat populations. The evidence base for both actions is currently insufficient to determine whether one approach would be more effective than the other.
summary_statements: There is no available evidence regarding the effectiveness of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts.
There is no available evidence regarding the effectiveness of protecting roost trees during forest operations.
No studies have been found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts.
No studies have been found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of protecting roost trees during forest operations.
The evidence base for training arborists to identify bat roosts and for protecting roost trees during forest operations is currently insufficient to determine which approach would be more effective.
